ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to think about scientific experimentation in the chemical biology field, basics of techniques used in the field

I learned so much about the principles underlying chemical biology! There was a large emphasis on developing our experimental design skills, which I thought was very beneficial to my general knowledge.
Introduction to chemical biology, particularly relating to proteins

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strength - recordings for reference while studying
weakness - 9am was pretty rough some days

we had pop quizzes at the beginning of the class but those got turned into problem sets, which made the class much more manageable.

Professor Malaker is a very considerate teacher. We began the class with pop quizzes, which were stressful and not very effective. However, Professor Malaker recognized this and asked us how to be a better teacher. We no longer had pop quizzes, but we were given other opportunities to grow as thinkers. I have tremendous respect for Professor Malaker: she wasnt afraid to admit that her pedagogical choice wasnt a perfect fit for the class.

I thought that the course was well structured all-around, and I learned much about different aspects of protein and carbohydrate chemical biology. My only complaint is that we had had problem sets instead of quizzes for the entire class and that we did not discuss the readings enough in person.

A lot of material, each lecture had like 50-60 slides to review and the professor went over them really quickly. There were also pop quizzes (at least in the beginning of the class until she took them away because we all hated them) which were extremely stressful and had really low averages (one average was 11/20). I also felt like Professor Malaker didn't do a great job at explaining things sometimes; she's so intelligent and knowledgeable about the subject but then when I didn't understand things it felt like she was annoyed trying to explain them when I didn't get it after her first explanation. She also didn't provide any information as to the final grades/what the curve would look like before the final so it was hard to know where we stood in relation to the rest of the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes! if interested in drug development/chemical biology spaces I would highly recommend. Just know it is a graduate course - it was a lot of work, especially as an undergrad.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student wanting to develop knowledge of chemical biology, particularly experimental design and mass spectrometry. Professor Malaker is and will continue to be big in the field of mass spectrometry, so its a privilege to learn from her.
I feel like I learned a lot and it will be useful because I do chemical biology research, but I found this class quite stressful and I wouldn't recommend to take it along with a heavy courseload.
